revisions.*:
'''Alan David Hickinbotham [[Order of Australia|AM]]''' (9 December 1925 – 25 May 2010) was an [[Australia]]n businessman and [[Australian rules football]] player and coach.

==Early life==
Hickinbotham was born on 9 December 1925 in [[Geelong, Victoria]]. During 1944 and 1945 he served in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] as a gunner.<ref name="columba1">{{cite web|url=http://www.stcolumba.com.au/Scholarship/Alan%20Hickinbotham%20Scholarship%20Broch_Sept09.pdf|title=Alan David Hickinbotham|work=The Alan Hickinbotham Scholarship|publisher=St Columba College|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref>

===Teaching===
In 1948 he graduated from the [[University of Adelaide]] with a Bachelor of Science and
Diploma of Education. Between 1949 and 1951 he taught science and mathematics at [[Geelong Grammar]].<ref name="columba1" />

==Business==
Hickinbotham founded the Hickinbotham Group of Companies in 1954, which became one of Australia's largest building companies, developing over 50 community estates in [[Adelaide]]. He was an influential member of the Housing Industry Association SA and worked to sponsor skilled immigrants from Britain to settle in Adelaide. He also had an interest in wineries in South Australia.<ref name="abc1">{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/05/26/2909879.htm|title=Hickinbotham lived full life in business and sport|last=Sexton|first=Mike|date=26 May 2010|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref><ref name="advertiser2">{{cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/business/hickinbotham-recogised-for-wine-serice/story-e6frede3-1111113121885?from=public_rss|title=Hickinbotham recogised for wine serice|date=8 March 2007|work=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]]|publisher=News Corporation|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref>

==Football==
Before his business career, Hickinbotham  played six matches as a key defender for [[Geelong Football Club]].<ref>{{AflRleague|ref=A/Alan_Hickinbotham.html}} Accessed 26 May 2010</ref> He later captain-coached [[South Adelaide Football Club]] and retained ties to the club until his death. South Adelaide renamed their home ground [[Alan Hickinbotham Oval]] in his honour. He played four representative games for [[South Australia Australian rules football team|South Australia]].<ref name="abc1" />

In the early 1970s, Hickinbotham  was part of a committee that drove the development of [[Football Park]], a dedicated Australian rules football ground for major matches in Adelaide. 

==Politics==
He unsuccessfully stood as a [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] candidate for the [[Division of Hawker]] in the [[Australian federal election, 1969|1969 Federal election]]. 

==Honours==
He was made a Member of the [[Order of Australia]] for "services to housing and urban development" in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hickinbotham, Alan David|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=870726&search_type=quick&showInd=true|work=It's An Honour: Australia celebrating Australians|publisher=Australian Government}}</ref><ref name="abc1" /> A scholarship at St Columba College in Adelaide is named in honour.<ref name="columba1" />

==Death==
Hickinbotham died in May 2010 after a long illness, aged 84.<ref name="abc1" /><ref name="advertiser1">{{cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/sa-builder-alan-hickinbotham-dies-after-long-illness/story-e6frea6u-1225871236841|title=SA builder Alan Hickinbotham dies after long illness|last=Robertson|first=Doug|coauthors=Silverman, Hannah|date=26 May 2010|work=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]]|publisher=News Corporation|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref>
